com.informix.jdbc

Class IfxResultSetMetaData

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.informix.jdbc.IfxResultSetMetaData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IfmxResultSetMetaData, java.sql.ResultSetMetaData, java.sql.Wrapper

    public class IfxResultSetMetaData
extends java.lang.Object
implements IfmxResultSetMetaData
    A ResultSetMetaData object can be used to find out about the types and properties of the columns in a ResultSet. ResultSetMetaData is a supplement of ResultSet to handle Column related information. Each ResultSet object can have either zero or one corresponding ResultSetMetaData object. Each ResultSetMetaData object will hold all column information in object instant variables. These instant variables got initialized by calling ResultSet object method getMetaData(). It will use protocal layer and issue an describe to database and get all column information. Fill these information into the ResultSetMetaData object. All the methods in ResultSetMetaData class just retrieve information from its instant variables and return to caller. One setColumnInfo(column) method for protocol layer to set these instant variables. Note: The only way to create ResultSetMetaData object is through calling ResultSet.getMetaData() method.

      • getColumnClassName

        public java.lang.String getColumnClassName(int column)
                                    throws java.sql.SQLException
        JDBC 2.0

        Return the fully qualified name of the Java class whose instances are manufactured if ResultSet.getObject() is called to retrieve a value from the column. ResultSet.getObject() may return a subClass of the class returned by this method.

        Specified by:
        getColumnClassName in interface java.sql.ResultSetMetaData
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException

      • parseTableName

        public static java.lang.String parseTableName(java.lang.String command)
        parseTableName Given the command string, get the table name out of it by looking for the identifier after certain words. Note that if the user has a database object called 'from', this parser is not smart enough to figure that out and eventually may cause ambiguity problems. We'll need to document this. Conforming to JDBC API reference manual, in case of select queries involving joins or in case of queries where no table name is involved we return an empty string. Also , if we can not determine table name for any reason , we return an empty string. If server implements FEA#165847 we may not have to parse the query at client end any more. Following are known cases (as of now !) which are not handled correctly by this method " UPDATE ONLY(super_tab) WHERE ....." "SELECT * FROM ONLY(super_tab)" Table name returned is "ONLY(super_tab)" "SELECT part_number, COUNT(*) * 100 AS how_many FROM 1000000 SAMPLES OF parts_sold GROUP BY part_number;" Table name returned is "1000000"

      • parseSetTableName

        public void parseSetTableName(java.lang.String command)
                       throws java.sql.SQLException
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException

      • findrowid

        protected int findrowid()
                 throws java.sql.SQLException
        Used by ResultSet() in order to support updatable cursors. This method returns the index of the column name 'rowid' if used specifically by the user in their query. This method also sets the local variable 'rowidx' to the index of the column within the resultset.
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException

      • findserial

        protected java.lang.String findserial()
                               throws java.sql.SQLException
        Used by ResultSet() in order to support updatable cursors. This method returns the column name when the column type of serial or serial8 is used specifically by the user in their query. It also sets the local variable serialidx to the index of the serial column within the resultset.
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException
